messages: eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (01:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: (a very late response) Put it in HTMLParser. That should be the "public interface"
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (01:31): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Godawful libxml bug == "Namespace Error" when you try to set a namespaced attribute.

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:32): so, looking at the websocket protocol, what constraints are enforced on the server regarding processing of the input?  is it an error if tab-delimited "header" lines are received?  what if "multi-line headers" are received?  basically, websockets looks like HTTP, but at what point does accepting HTTP input that's more lax than the websocket client input constitute a violation of the protocol...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:34): what do you mean by "enforced"?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:34): the protocol spec says what you're expected to suport
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:34): support
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:34): as a server-side author
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:35): s/enforced/required/, then
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:35): the client is required to follow the exact steps given in the draft
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:35): http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hixie-thewebsocketprotocol-12#page-15
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:36): the server, it seems, has latitude to accept more than that
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:36): is the server required to accept input from a client that doesn't actually follow the strictures of the client-processing section?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:36): yes, I've been looking at that
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (01:37): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: My idea is to implement SimpleTree and watch our performance problems melt away ^_^
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:37): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: the server doesn't have to do any error handling, if that's what you mean
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:38): that seems...dangerous
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:38): not in any tangible sense
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): the ability to control authors is basically nil
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): so getting them to implement particular error handling behavior... forget it
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:38): but in the sense of I-can-plausibly-believe-this-will-bite-us-at-some-point
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:38): no, this is error handling server-side
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:39): right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:39): authors write the server side
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:39): oh, there are authors on both sides
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:39): hum, this might work then
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): i could write a new section
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): which is "full requirements for server-side implementors that actually follow specs"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): if you like
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): might not be a bad idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): if you do think that would be useful, send a mail to whatwg, and i'll add it

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:41): I'm just looking at this from the POV of the Mozilla bug, in which our HTTP server is being lightly hijacked to support all this, worried about being more generous in accepting input than it should be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:41): is this for testing or for production?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): for regression testing, it doesn't matter what the server does, it just has to check that the client sends exactly the right bytes
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:42): I try not to differentiate the two when I write servers (or rather, when I write the one server I've written so far)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): a regression test suite server and a production server are completely different
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): you can't, e.g., use apache to do serious regression testing of client-side http behaviour
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:42): yes, but that doesn't mean one shouldn't make an effort not to make it safe-by-default
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): i don't really see how a regression-testing server framework can be unsafe -- it has to accept any input whatsoever

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:44): hm, I think we're talking about different meanings; "production" to me is use in which inputs are unconstrained, "regression-testing" in the sense of inputs are constrained but may intentionally be random junk
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:44): constrained by whatever's in the test suite using it
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:48): on an unrelated note, reading RFC-style formatting rather than whatwg-style formatting is no fun :-(
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:48): especially since things like "find" don't work due to ASCII text-decorations
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:50): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: an "in production" server is one serving end-user traffic
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:50): we agree on that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:50): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: a regression testing server is one used to test another tool's implementation
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:51): sure, just say that I like my regression testing servers to have as rigorous an implementation as a production server must have
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:51): so an in-production server can do things like disconnect if the input is bogus
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:51): but a regression testing server needs to report pass/fail for all inputs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:03): http://larry.masinter.net/versioning-html.html
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:03): (from www-tag)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:05): eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2: I've fixed another test case (actually, I've fixed the test runner).

eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: ping?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2: here

eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Can you comment on what IN_FOREIGN_CONTENT is supposed to do when we are processing an HTML element as "in body", and that element wants us to change the mode?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): um
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): nothing beyond what the spec says as far as i can tell
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): how do you mean?

eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:27): As far as I can tell, the spec doesn't record that you were originally in "in foreign content" when it hops to another mode, so when you pop out of that, you stay in "in body", and don't go back to "in foreign content"
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:27): I just wanted to verify that this was true before sending mail
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (02:40): Augh, damn user agents.
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (02:40): They create a plethora of <a> nodes when I wrap some block item inside an <a> tag.
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (02:41): I guess I have overestimated the current support of html5.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2: minimal testcase? do you mean like <svg><table> ?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:49): <svg><foreignObject><table></table></foreignObject></svg>
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:50): Uhh, make that <svg><foreignObject><table></table></foreignObject><g/></svg>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:51): eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2: wouldn't you switch back to foreign content when you reset after the </table>?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:52): Possibly. Let me check that part of the spec again
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (02:53): Yep, looks like it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:57): anyone here understand RDF/XML?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:01): I figured RDF/XML would be mostly self-explanatory, but if you're asking that question, I guess not
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:16): Is there any good way of just getting messages about changes to the html5lib spec that are w.r.t. tokenization/tree-building?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:16): erm, s/html5lib/html5/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:17): yeah, look for 't' in the first field
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:17): Hm... so I still have to sign up for html5-commits, and just filter out things w/o t in the first field?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:18): or you can use the tracker
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:18): it has little check boxes that filter out everything else
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:18): note that i often screw up
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:18): so don't rely on it too much :-)
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:18): So, "Affects Tools" is what I want?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:19): Man, I wish this had an RSS feed
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (03:19): (and an easier way of unchecking everything)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:20): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:20): you can provide patches, i believe
